_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installation of locked fence around containers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Elanco a division of Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly), a global research-based pharmaceutical corporation, is a world leader in developing products and services that enhance animal health, wellness and performance.  Elanco manufactures animal health products at its Clinton Laboratories facility (Clinton Laboratories).  Clinton Laboratories is located approximately five miles north of Clinton, Indiana.  Operations at Clinton Laboratories began in June of 1970.  Clinton Laboratories is located on a 700-acre site.  The plant itself includes 70 buildings on 200 acres.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Clinton Laboratories has designed and implemented, including:

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3. The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps
4. Five-year accident history
5. The emergency response program
6. Planned changes to improve safety

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

Clinton Laboratories is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner.  This is especially important for those processes using hazardous chemicals. Clinton Laboratories has numerous systems in place to manage these chemicals.  Elanco uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment. Clinton Laboratories, accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by the use of these chemicals.

Clinton Laboratories has a Plant Emergency Response Plan that contains procedures on how to handle emergencies that occur.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification o

f local authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.

Clinton Laboratories plays an active role in its Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  A primary goal of the LEPC is to protect local citizens by developing and maintaining a coordinated emergency response plan and working with industry to minimize the impacts of chemical hazards.  Through the LEPC, citizens can obtain information about hazardous substances handled at local facilities and about emergency planning efforts designed to successfully cope with accidents if they occur.  The LEPC maintains a coordinated emergency response plan for the community detailing operational procedures to be followed in the event of an accident involving hazardous materials.  The plan is available for public inspection.

Clinton Laboratories actively supports local community outreach efforts through Community Advisory Panels and neighbor groups.  These panels provide useful feedback from the community and advise Lilly on community issues. Lilly also hosts plant tours and informative evening programs for nearby neighbors.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

Clinton Laboratories is divided into two main functional areas.  Animal Health manufacturing, on the south end of the plant, manufactures feed additives and other animal health products.  These products are finished and packaged on site for worldwide delivery to customers.  The second functional area, site services, is located primarily in the center of the plant, with other buildings throughout the plant. Services provided include: steam, water, heat transfer media, electricity, and maintenance support. The services area provides support for Animal Health areas.  The facility has a Title V operating permit under the Clean Air Act.

The following regulated substances are handled at Clinton Laboratories in quantities above the threshold quantities established under the RMP regulations: 

TOXICS:  anhydrous ammoni

a, chlorine

FLAMMABLES - None
      

3. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS: 

Clinton Laboratories is subject to Indiana OSHA's Process Safety Management requirements, as well as other Indiana OSHA requirements.  The facility is also subject to regulation by other agencies, including the Indiana Department of Environmental Management and the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

Specific prevention programs include conducting pre-startup and design hazard assessments, proactive maintenance programs, routine vessel inspections, emergency response training, safe to work programs, employee and contractor safety programs, and accident investigation programs.

As a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC), Lilly participates in a program known as Responsible Care. The purpose of Responsible Care is to commit companies to performance improvement in health, safety, and environmental quality. The Responsible Care initiative is driven by the following guiding principles: 
¿ To lead in ethical ways that increasingly benefits society, the economy and the environment.  
¿ To design and develop products that can be manufactured, transported, used and disposed of or recycled safely.   
¿ To work with customers, carriers, suppliers, distributors and contractors to foster the safe and secure use, transport and disposal of chemicals and provide hazard and risk information that can be accessed and applied in their operations and products.  
¿ To design and operate facilities in a safe, secure and environmentally sound manner.   
¿ To instill a culture throughout all levels of the organizations to continually identify, reduce and manage process safety risks.   
¿ To promote pollution prevention, minimization of waste and conservation of energy and other critical resources at every stage of the life cycle of products.   
¿ To cooperate with governments at all levels and organizations in the development

stabilize a hazardous area and rescue employees who may need help.
Team undergoes rigorous training in fire fighting and/or hazmat response.

CONFINED SPACE RESCUE TEAM
This group specializes in rescue from tanks, pits and other confined areas. They are trained to use ropes and mechanical rescue techniques.
 
FIRST RESPONDERS
First Responders are trained to render emergency medical aid.  Some members are also trained in confined space rescue, fire and hazmat response. All are certified in CPR, first aid and defibrillation.

COMMUNICATIONS DISPATCHERS
Communications dispatchers are trained to manage the communications hub in plant security during emergency situations.

6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Clinton Laboratories is committed to continuous safety improvement and risk reduction.  A system to conduct Process Hazard Reviews is in place.  The system will assure Process Hazard Reviews are conducted for each of the appropriate processes at Clinton Laboratories.

The mechanical systems are routinely tested to insure proper operation and performance.  Any problems found are corrected and opportunities for improvement are noted and evaluated.    

Drills are also conducted to practice and improve the procedures for responding to emergencies.

of effective and efficient safety, health, environmental and security laws, regulations and standards.   
¿ To support education and research on the health, safety, environmental effects and security of products and processes.   
¿ To communicate product, service and process risks to stakeholders and listen to and consider their perspectives.   
¿ To make continual progress toward a goal of no accidents, injuries or harm to human health and the environment from products and operations and openly report health, safety, environmental and security performance.   
¿ To seek continual improvement in the integrated Responsible Care Management System® to address environmental, health, safety and security performance. 
¿ To promote Responsible Care by encouraging and assisting other companies to adhere to these Guiding Principles.


In order to participate in ACC's Responsible Care program, Lilly has committed to meet these guiding principles and incorporate them into the way it does business.  Lilly has also committed to uphold the following program elements, which are the pillars of the Responsible Care program:
¿ Adhering to the Responsible Care Guiding Principles  
¿ Implementing the Responsible Care Security Code 
¿ Measuring and publicly reporting performance, using the Responsible Care Performance Measures 
¿ Applying the modern Responsible Care Management System to achieve and verify results.


Lilly is proud to participate in this forward-looking industry initiative. It is one way Lilly can demonstrate its commitment to ensuring the safety of its employees and the community and to protecting the environment.

4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
Clinton Laboratories keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  In the five-year period from August 2007 to August 2012, Clinton Laboratories has had no accidents as defined in the 40 CFR 68.42.

5. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AT

CLINTON LABORATORIES
The Clinton Laboratories Incident Management System is comprehensive.  It includes elements such as:   site emergency response plan, employee protective actions, the emergency management organization, and implementation of a response, post incident procedures and building specific pre-emergency plans.  The plan is executed through a cooperative effort between the site's management support team, full time emergency response teams, local law enforcement, and local emergency management. The on-site emergency response capabilities include full time emergency response teams (described below), fire and spill response equipment, rescue apparatus, ambulance service, and clinic. Regular drills test readiness and help employees practice responses to alarms and incidents.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAMS 
Site emergency response team members participate in frequent training conducted both internally and externally. In an emergency situation, a member of the plant security staff fulfills the incident commander role. The Incident Commander directs all field response activities and makes regular reports to the management support team as the incident proceeds.  The Incident Commander and Incident Team Leaders direct the specific tactical actions of the emergency response teams, described below.  Approximately 70 employees, who hold full time jobs elsewhere on the site, make up the various emergency response teams.  Most of the employees are cross-trained on more than one team.  A brief description of the teams follows.

FIRE BRIGADE/HAZARDOUS MATERIAL (HAZMAT) TEAM
This is a combined team of both fire fighting and hazardous material spill response.
The fire brigade is a structural fire fighting organization trained to respond to industrial fires.  The Haz Mat responders are trained to the Technician level.
Hazardous material response includes responding to hazardous spills or vapor releases. Responders are trained to use proper equipment and techniques to
